item.title: U.S. Says It Erred in Deporting Student Traveling for Thanksgiving
item.description: The Trump administration acknowledged it mistakenly deported a college student to Honduras despite a court order barring the removal. But the government has not moved to drop the case.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Any Lucia Lopez Belloza's lawyer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Any Lucía López Belloza’s high school graduation in Texas. She was detained and later deported in late November while trying to surprise her family with a visit.

item.title: Venezuela’s Interim Leader Delivers State of the Union Address
item.description: In her State of the Union address, Delcy Rodríguez echoed her predecessors’ fiery rhetoric but tried to hew to President Trump’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Patricia Sulbarán
item.media:credit: Ariana Cubillos/Associated Press
item.media:description: Venezuela’s interim president, Delcy Rodríguez, delivering a speech at the National Assembly in Caracas on Thursday.

item.title: Former Senator Kyrsten Sinema Accused of Affair With Member of Security Team
item.description: In a lawsuit, the ex-wife of Ms. Sinema’s onetime staff member accused her of showering him with gifts and breaking up their marriage.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Senator Kyrsten Sinema at the Capitol last month.

item.title: What Did the White House and Denmark Agree to on Greenland? Depends Whom You Ask.
item.description: The White House and Denmark contradicted each other in public about what they had agreed to this week as President Trump continued to demand U.S. ownership of Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Jeffrey Gettleman and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Marko Djurica/Reuters
item.media:description: A Danish military vessel sailing near the old harbor of Nuuk, Greenland’s capital, on Wednesday.

item.title: The Nobel Peace Prize Medal Has Been Sold Before for Millions
item.description: The Nobel Committee has said the prize cannot be transferred, but it has been sold in a few auctions over the award’s history.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
item.media:description: Since the 1980s, the Nobel medal has been made with recycled gold.

item.title: Judge Proposes Restricting Deportation of Student Activists
item.description: In a case over the First Amendment rights of noncitizen scholars, a federal judge proposed extending protections to members of two academic groups behind a lawsuit.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Scott Heins for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mahmoud Khalil speaking in Manhattan last August. Earlier on Thursday, a federal appeals court ruled that he was improperly ordered released by a Federal District Court judge last year. Academic groups have raised alarms over the government’s efforts to deport him.

item.title: N.S.A. Nominee Promises to Protect Elections From Foreign Interference
item.description: President Trump fired the National Security Agency’s chief back in April and has weakened cyberattack protections.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Francis L. Donovan, left, and Lt. Gen. Joshua M. Rudd testified in front of the Senate Armed Services Committee on Capitol Hill on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Threatens to Invoke the Insurrection Act and Send Troops to Minnesota
item.description: The law, which was last invoked in 1992, could allow President Trump to deploy the military inside the United States. Doing so would be a major escalation.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump in the Oval Office on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Forces Seize Sixth Oil Tanker Linked to Venezuela
item.description: The Coast Guard boarded and seized the Russian-flagged tanker, originally named Veronica, in a pre-dawn operation in the Caribbean Sea.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Nicholas Nehamas and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: US Southern Command, via Reuters
item.media:description: An image from video released by the U.S. military showing the oil tanker Galileo, previously named Veronica, in the Caribbean on Thursday.

item.title: Pentagon Will ‘Refocus’ Military Publication Stars and Stripes
item.description: The agency’s chief spokesman outlined plans to intervene in the previously independent newspaper’s coverage.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple
item.media:credit: Godfrey/Associated Press
item.media:description: Two soldiers from the 25th Infantry Division reading an issue of Stars and Stripes in Cu Chi, South Vietnam, in 1969. The military newspaper has been published continuously since 1942.

item.title: University of Arkansas Withdraws Job Offer for Emily Suski Over Transgender Stance
item.description: The University of Arkansas withdrew a job offer to a legal scholar after state officials learned that she had signed a legal brief concerning transgender athletes, lawmakers said.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Melyssa St. Michael for The New York Times
item.media:description: The University of Arkansas came under political pressure to rescind the choice, state lawmakers said.

item.title: Hesitant to Visit the U.S. for the World Cup? We Want to Hear From You.
item.description: International soccer fans face hurdles like travel bans, long visa delays and high ticket prices for U.S. matches. Will they be enough to keep you away?
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:credit: Antonin Thuillier/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: High ticket prices and stringent visa requirements could keep fans of teams like Argentina, the 2022 World Cup champions, from attending matches in United States this summer.

item.title: State and Federal Lawmakers Want Data Centers to Pay More for Energy
item.description: Despite many proposals, there is little consensus among governors, lawmakers and tech executives about exactly how much the companies behind data centers should pay for electricity.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Scott Ball for The New York Times
item.media:description: A data center built by OpenAI and Oracle in Abilene, Texas.

item.title: Did a Supreme Court Loss Embolden Trump on the Insurrection Act?
item.description: In refusing to let the president deploy National Guard troops in Illinois under an obscure law, the justices may have made him more apt to invoke greater powers.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis on Monday night.

item.title: Madison Sheahan, ICE’s No. 2 Official and a Trump Ally, Leaves to Run for House in Ohio
item.description: Madison Sheahan, a top enforcer of President Trump’s immigration crackdown, said she would step down to challenge Representative Marcy Kaptur, a Democrat.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Madison Sheahan in November. As she announced her House campaign, she called herself “a Trump conservative” and focused on her work helping carry out the president’s deportation agenda.

item.title: Harvey Pratt, Who Designed the Native American Veterans Memorial, Dies at 84
item.description: A self-taught artist, he also spent more than half a century creating forensic sketches and reconstructions for law-enforcement agencies.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.category: National Museum of the American Indian

item.title: Trump Outlines Health Care Proposals as Prices and Premiums Rise
item.description: The long-awaited plan would leave much to Congress and calls for payments to health savings accounts rather than insurance subsidies, among other broad proposals.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater, Rebecca Robbins, Margot Sanger-Katz and Michael Gold
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump released a video promoting what he calls “the great health care plan.”

item.title: Israel and Arab Nations Ask Trump to Refrain From Attacking Iran
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel asked the president to postpone any planned attack. Israeli and Arab officials fear Iran could retaliate by striking their countries.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel with President Trump last month in Florida. The Israeli leader spoke to Mr. Trump on Wednesday, the same day that the president claimed Iran had stopped killing protesters.

item.title: Coinbase, the Biggest U.S. Crypto Company, Asserts Its Power in Washington
item.description: The top executive of the crypto exchange Coinbase scuttled a planned Senate committee vote on a major cryptocurrency bill after voicing his concerns, a sign of the company’s clout.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: A planned vote on a cryptocurrency bill on Thursday was canceled after Brian Armstrong, Coinbase’s chief executive, objected to the measure in a social media post on Wednesday evening.

item.title: U.S. Cuts Health Aid and Ties It to Funding Pledges by African Governments
item.description: The Trump administration has signed $11 billion in agreements with African nations, in deals tied to foreign policy goals.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times
item.media:description: A health clinic in Mhlosheni, Eswatini, in May. Health funding from the U.S. to Eswatini — where a quarter of adults live with H.I.V. — would drop by 34 percent under the new agreement between the two countries.

item.title: Under Trump, a Shift Toward ‘Absolute Immunity’ for ICE
item.description: Since the fatal shooting of Renee Good in Minneapolis, administration officials have defended the use of deadly force, which agency guidelines say should be a last resort.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz and Nicholas Nehamas
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Newly recruited Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents at a training center last year. President Trump and administration officials have given tacit approval for more aggressive tactics by the agency.

item.title: Abolish ICE? It’s a Slogan Some Democratic Critics of ICE Would Abolish.
item.description: As Democrats grow more alarmed about the Trump administration’s aggressive immigration raids in American cities, some worry that calls to eliminate the agency will distract from efforts to rein it in.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some Democrats who are critical of the Trump administration’s immigration raids in cities across the nation are urging the party not to embrace calls to “Abolish ICE.”

item.title: Cyberattack in Venezuela Demonstrated Precision of U.S. Capabilities
item.description: Lt. Gen. Joshua M. Rudd appeared before the Senate Armed Services Committee, which is weighing his nomination to lead the U.S. Cyber Command, but provided little new information about the operation.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Sunrise in Caracas on Jan. 3. Turning off the power in Caracas and interfering with radar allowed U.S. military helicopters to move into the country undetected on their mission to capture Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: The U.S. Is Pressing Mexico to Allow U.S. Forces to Fight Cartels
item.description: The United States is escalating pressure on the Mexican government to permit the U.S. military to target fentanyl labs, according to American officials.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: White powder, purportedly finished fentanyl, sitting on a table in a makeshift lab operated by the Sinaloa cartel.

item.title: Leading Prediction Firms Share a Commonality: Donald Trump Jr.
item.description: Traders in companies with ties to the president’s eldest son can bet on the outcome of events the president affects.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:credit: Mark Schiefelbein/Associated Press
item.media:description: Donald Trump Jr. is both an investor in and an unpaid adviser to Polymarket, and a paid adviser to Kalshi, the two biggest prediction markets.

item.title: Judge to Weigh Next Steps in Student Activist Deportations Case
item.description: The hearing on Thursday followed up on the court’s sweeping finding in September that noncitizen students had the same free speech rights as citizens.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Ryan Murphy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mahmoud Khalil and Mohsen Mahdawi, two international students detained by the Trump administration, at a vigil in New York last September.
